awd_titl_txt: Engineering the Anisotropy of Magnesium Alloys for Enhanced Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnesium is the lightest metal that can be used in load bearing applications in various alloy forms. However, current processing techniques for forming and shaping are limited to elevated temperatures, which drive high production costs and a negative environmental footprint. This award supports fundamental research to provide strategies for producing fracture-resistant Mg alloys, including during forming operations. A key departure from current thinking is to engineer an essential feature of these materials, the directionality of their properties, which is conventionally thought of as deleterious, hence to be mitigated. Accelerated insertion of Mg alloys is potentially transformative in a multi-billion dollar economy of the transportation industry. In addition, use of these lightweight structural materials will lead to reduction in fuel consumption and emissions with a positive impact on the environment, including in manufacturing. The project activities will create an interdisciplinary research environment for both undergraduate and graduate students and investigate teaching methods in processing and manufacturing. 

The research will elucidate the relationship between the plastic anisotropy of Mg alloys and their fracture resistance and formability. The underlying hypothesis is that the anisotropy of Mg alloys can be engineered to develop materials with unprecedented strength and ductility. To test the hypothesis, materials sharing the same chemical composition and microstructure but having different textures will be produced in bulk and sheet form and characterized for their plastic strength, formability and fracture properties. A metrics-based methodology will be developed for correlating plastic anisotropy with measures of fracture and formability. Discrete dislocation dynamics, continuum damage mechanics analyses and simulations as well as investigations of microscopic damage mechanisms will be carried out to gain further insight into the success or failure of such correlations. The project will therefore help answer important questions such as: (i) Is material anisotropy intrinsically deleterious? If not, how can it be engineered for enhanced performance? (ii) Does enhanced ductility translate into cost-effective formability? (iii) Are there any achievable textures that result in types of anisotropy that prevent shear failure? (iv) How does the anisotropy manifest at dislocation scales? Inquiry into these issues will follow a holistic approach that brings together materials science, mechanics and manufacturing.

por.por_cntn:
This hypothesis-driven research concerns technologically important magnesium alloys sought for light-weighting in transportation and defense. Their common disadvantage is the orientation dependence (anisotropy) of mechanical properties, widely believed to be the cause for their low formability near the ambient. Past efforts to eliminate the anisotropy have been unsuccessful. The hypothesis is that the anisotropy of Mg alloys can be engineered to develop materials with unprecedented formability.

 

Project activities involved experiments, modeling and simulation at multiple length scales. The main outcome pertains to a user-friendly index of ductility, introduced from first principles of micromechanics in plastically anisotropic materials that fail by internal cavitation. The developed index provides a practical way to guide the design of anisotropy with the specific aim to enhance ductility. It played an essential role in verifying the research hypothesis. Using a technique of severe plastic deformation known as equal-channel angular extrusion, the team was able to process materials that have a common mean grain size and a common chemical composition but differed in their polycrystalline texture, hence in their anisotropy. Qualitatively consistent with theory, the ductility of the processed materials was found to rank-order as predicted by the developed anisotropy index.

 

While certain forms of anisotropy were found to enhance ductility, their potential effect on failure by instability had to be mitigated. Detailed analyses of shear fracture were carried out using three-dimensional simulations. The analyses were conducted under the simplest configurations possible in an attempt to develop basic understanding. Shear failure was predicted in round-notched bars, consistent with experimental observations. It was found that the angle of the shear crack was determined by the magnitude of plastic anisotropy, not by the misorientation of the axes of anisotropy, although a small misorientation was needed to trigger shear failure. It is hoped that this type of simulations will lead to developing a second, instability/formability index that may be in competition in some cases with the ductility index.

 

The extent to which crystallographic aspects play a role in the plastic growth and coalescence of voids in highly textured Mg alloys was critically examined. This is so because the anisotropy index theory is predicated on the basis that failure occurs due to internal cavitation. Micromechanical, three-dimensional simulations were carried out using crystal plasticity in order to apportion the plastic anisotropy effects from those caused by mere crystallographic aspects. It would be straightforward for currently available models of ductile damage to capture some of the uncovered effects provided that plastic anisotropy is properly accounted for. On the other hand, the complexity of the rate and state of void evolution, e.g. due to twinning-induced crystal reorientation, stands in contrast with current homogenization-based models.

 

The transition to accurate multiscale modeling for Mg alloys required a fundamental understanding of the effects of deformation mechanisms and dynamic recrystallization on ductility.  Experimental work and crystal plasticity simulations were combined to understand the activation of each slip or twin system with strain hardening evolution. Experimental results provided insights on causes of crack nucleation by isolating certain deformation mechanisms with orientation selection. Furthermore, the evolution of recrystallization with temperature was studied. It was concluded that recrystallized grains formed necklace-like structures, which were favorable nucleation sites for fracture at high temperatures. At these same temperatures yield strengths from the all orientations tended to converge with considerable improvement in ductility. The exact transition from slip and twin dominant deformation to pyramidal and dynamic recrystallization dominant deformation was successfully mapped.

 

The anisotropy effect on ductility index was further examined using cup drawing tests. Crystal plasticity simulations and inverse optimization were used to design several processing routes with varying anisotropy indices. Thin sheet blanks were cut from processed plates and tested. The exact textures were mapped to these blanks so earing and tearing effects could be directly attributed to differences in texture. Additional tests are currently being conducted.

 

The project has involved one undergraduate minority student in research and enabled to engage all participants in international collaborations with leadings institutions in France and Australia. Fundamental notions about anisotropic plasticity have enhanced a summer school on computational materials science across the scales, organized at Texas A&M. A new collaboration was started with Los Alamos National Laboratory to account for grain fragmentation and dynamic recrystallization in the constitutive models. One doctoral student spent 3 months at Los Alamos.

 

More broadly, understanding potentially competing roles of plastic anisotropy in setting limits to ductility or formability, either by internal cavitation or by plastic instability pervades beyond material processing, in particular to geological materials where shear fractures and void formation in ductile rocks in the lower and middle parts of the Earth’s crust are key mechanisms in plate tectonics. The project has thus opened new avenues of collaborative research in geophysics with colleagues at Texas A&M University.
